This rifle has a replacement .308 barrel with a nice clean bore. Trigger group has (as far as I can tell) all Springfield Armory GI parts in excellent condition. Bold has the correct drawing number for the receiver. (A8)

I know that the T37 flash hider isn't quite correct, but it appears that Arlington Ordnance included it on a few of their rifles. (I have only found one other example.)

Here is what my research has indicated. Be aware that this might not be perfectly accurate, as there is a lot of controversy, misinformation and myth surrounding this gun. It's hard to know who knows what they are talking about and who doesn't.

The "Tanker" has an interesting history.  The Government built 150 of them, and Springfield Armory built two in the US. and only one is known to survive. Judging from the specimen at the Springfield Armory Museum, they were real chop-jobs with a lot of crude filing and hand fitting.

Later in the 60's some companies found that they could sell a Garand for more if they shortened it and called it a Tanker. Some were good, some were horrible.

In the interest of any potential buyers I felt that I needed to take this one out and test it. It functions perfectly. I noticed that the charging handle takes a slight forward nudge to allow the bolt to close after the clip is inserted, but this is very common for even the nicest unmodified Garands.

Feel free to do a search for M1 Garand Tanker and see what you find. You might start with this:
